General Information.Habitat: Free-living and aquatic, found in fresh stagnant water with abundant organic matter.

Pellicle.Description: Thin, firm, and flexible membrane covering the body
Pellicle.Composition: Made by a regular arrangement of microtubules

Cilia.Description: Numerous cilia covering the entire body surface, acting as locomotory organelles
Special Groups: Dorsal penniculus (Opposite in case of Pharynx)

Movement.Longitudinal Row: Moves simultaneously one by one (Metachronous rhythm)

Cilia.Role of ATP: ATP plays a crucial role in the movement of cilia

Trichocysts.Description: Peculiar bottle-shaped organelles in the ectoplasm
Trichocysts.Function: Organs of attachment, previously thought to be organs of offence and defence

Structure.Shaft: Anterior end becomes very long when discharged
Structure.Length: Discharged trichocyst is ten times longer than undischarged one

Contractile Vacuoles.Number: Two, permanently open on the dorsal surface
Contractile Vacuoles.Structure: Each vacuole has 6-10 radiating canals/accessory vacuoles

Food Vacuoles.Movement: Food vacuole moves along a definite course (Cyclosis) within the streaming endoplasm

Function.Description: Genetic reserve of the cell, controls reproductive activities

Favorite Food.Name: Tetrahymena
Favorite Food.Description: Another ciliate protozoa, used in biological research

Nutrition.Oral Groove: Takes food through oral groove/peristomal groove at the left side of the anterior end of the body
Nutrition.Cyclosis: Ensures uniform distribution of digested food material

Cytopyge or Cytoproct.Description: Temporary anus, situated on the ventral surface of the oral groove

Taxes.Response: Shows negative response and moves against water current
Taxes.Reaction: Contact with a foreign body induces avoiding reaction
Taxes.Electrotaxis: Moves towards the cathode (negative charge) under weak current

Process: Paramecium stops feeding and oral groove disappears
Macronucleus divides amitotically, micronucleus divides mitotically
Division occurs at a right angle to the body axis
Two daughter Paramecia are produced: Proter (anterior) and Opisthe (posterior)
Binary fission occurs during favorable conditions
Time": "Half an hour to 2 hours, 2-3 times a day

Sexual.Description: Temporary union of two individuals of different mating types for the exchange of micronuclear material
Functions: Brings about nuclear reorganization and rejuvenation
Process: Two Paramecia of different mating types unite ventrally by their oral grooves (Conjugants)
Macronucleus disintegrates and is absorbed by cytoplasm
Micronucleus divides twice, one division being reductional
Functional nucleus divides into female and male pronucleus
Male pronuclei are exchanged and fusion occurs, forming a diploid zygote nucleus (Synkaryon)
Zygote nucleus divides, producing macronuclei and micronuclei
Binary fission occurs, resulting in 8 daughter Paramecia

Autogamy.Result: Two daughter Paramecia from each individual

Cytogamy.Description: Two individuals come in contact without cell membrane breakdown or nuclear exchange

Endomixis.Description: Asexual reproduction where macronucleus disappears, and micronucleus divides without fusion
Endomixis.Result: Four daughter Paramecia from each individual

Hemixis.Description: Purification act; reconstitution of macronucleus without any changes in micronucleus

Kappa Particle.Description: Special particle in cytoplasm, present in some Paramecia
Kappa Particle.Strain: Paramecia with Kappa particles are called killer strain
Kappa Particle.Effect: Sensitive strain Paramecia die when conjugating with killer strain Paramecia
